Great, informative video! I'm a 44 year old woman with oily, acne prone and textured skin who is a new K-beauty convert...I currently use Agency tretinoin treatment for anti-aging and I enjoy, as a complement to my anti-aging skincare products from Agency, the Snail Rescue purifying face wash from Peach Slices (I think they may be affiliated with Peach and Lily), but Peach Slices regardless, is a Korean brand. I've also used the Peach Slices Snail Rescue oil-free moisturizer, which is fabulous and super lightweight. I also have the Peach Slices Snail Rescue Blemish Busting toner....all of this Snail Rescue line contains 95% snail mucin concentrate and I've enjoyed using this toner to calm my skin as well from the tretinoin, as the Snail Rescue products also contain Centella and tea tree oil. For my sunscreen, I had to go with an Asian sunscreen due to their superior filters and luxurious feel, because nobody wants a tretinoin sunburn from an inferior sunscreen. I rotate between the (Korean) Biore UV Aqua Rich weightless moisturizer w broad spectrum SPF 50, which is great because it does double duty as both my SPF and provides moisture for my oily skin without having to apply two separate products and THEN apply makeup and a bunch of other products to my face as I do most days. The only downside to the Biore UV Aqua Rich is that it's NOT water-resistant and there are plenty of days when I sweat, either from the dry heat where I live (Las Vegas, NV) or from indoor heating, heat styling, hormonal changes, you name it. I found a great water resistant sunscreen that I've been loving (it was recommended by Dr. Jenny Liu here on YouTube), and it's the Kose Suncut UV Perfect Essence SPF 50 PA++++. It's water resistant, moisturizing enough to act as my AM moisturizer and behaves beautifully under makeup....which by the way, I'm next going to purchase the very viral Tir Tir Red Cushion foundation and also,I believe you may have influenced me to try the Haruharu Wonder Black Rice moisture cleanser. Congrats on all your well-deserved success and thanks for the Stylevana discount code!

I've been to South Korea. It's funny how people go nuts over Korean skin products, yet so many people in Korea use the plainest Nivea cream and THEY LOVE IT. I do like using their cultural 7 veil approach of just layering moisture (even if it's the same essence, or toner). I find a lot of value in just layering. Elf is still my favourite toner (I don't get SKII. I hate the scent and overall, just didn't like it). I do like Dr. Jart essence but it's a bit too strong to use every single day. I love Dr. Jart yellow cream. Thank you for making the video. I really appreciate you sharing all your knowledge. I might buy a few things from Stylevana. Thank you again.

Just a warning to anyone new to skincare here ‚ö†Ô∏è‚ö†Ô∏è YOU DO NEED A LOTION SUNSCREEN, especially if the UV index is 3 or above some time during the day. By only using a stick sunscreen, you're applying less than the 2mg/cm¬≤ at which SPF tests are done! THIS MEANS YOU'RE NOT GETTING THE FULL PROTECTION MARKED ON THE LABEL. The amount of protection that you get from your sunscreen highly depends on the amount you're using. For your entire face, it's regularly around 2 finger lenghts worth of lotion sunscreen (and 1 additional one for your neck). You probably should also reapply your sunscreen every two hours if you're staying in the sun for a while (this is where a stick sunscreen really shines, bc they're so easy to use). Although MOST IMPORTANTLY, the best protection against UV damage is sun avoidance (try not to stand in direct sunlight when possible, even when wearing sunscreen!). SEEK SHADE!
If the sunscreen stick isn't even protecting me properly then why should I even use it for reapplication? What's the use of a sunscreen stick then?

‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@@SassModeOn check out Lab Muffin's video on sun sticks. They can provide the advertised SPF, but the amount you would need to apply is huge, so it's very difficult to apply enough. So it may not be worth it. I guess it's more convenient when reapplying or touching up patches isn't convenient with a normal sunscreen and still better than nothing, or could be used just for lips or something

I'm new to all of this... what are the main products we need to have in a skin care routine? 1. Makeup remover 2. Cleanser 3.hydrating oils? Etc etc I don't want to buy so much and just add it to my face not even knowing why I need it. Do we need a thousand products to get luxurious skin or can we clean the face, then wash, then hydrate and keep it moving? Idk if you can understand what I'm saying lol I tried to simplify it as much as possible

The basics are a cleanser and sunscreen if dry skin then the basics would be a cleanser a moisturizer and a sunscreen if oily skin then am routine should be cleanser then sunscreen (most sunscreens are moisturizers hence why no need for a separate moisturizer) and the pm routine would be cleanser then a light weight moisturizer if dry skin then am skin care routine would be cleanser (optional can use just water) then moisturizer then sunscreen and at night cleanse then moisturize. for easier and better removal of makeup and sunscreen use micellar water or a cleansing oil at night before the regular cleanser. These are the basics and if u don‚Äôt have a problem in ur skin that needs to be fixed then there is no need for more products

DO NOT, and I repeat DO NOT use stick sunscreens as your only sunscreen. Lab Muffin Beauty Science made a great video why they are not enough. You need a regular sunscreen as the base for them to work properly. They are a nice way to re-apply, but don't work as your only sunscreen. Because you need a hefty amount to reach the 50 SPF rating.
Tried many Korean brands, iUnik was nice but I ended up with almost all Purito now. I just love that brand, it's been wonderful for my skin.

You literally can't overapply the stick sunscreen, to reach that spf on the label you need to do like 30 swipes, which nobody does. That's why it is better for reapplication rather than base protection.

Does anyone know if it's ok to use a cleansing balm and a cleansing oil? Like I'm currently using a cleansing balm to remove my makeup... if I wanted to incorporate a cleansing oil should that be its own step or should I use the oil in replace of the balm? Would the oil work to remove my makeup?

If you want to try out a cleansing oil, it would replace the balm. Cleansing oils and balms both work great in taking off makeup. Personally I own a cleansing oil, a cleansing balm, and a water-based cleanser. When I'm at home I usually use the cleansing oil first and a water-based cleanser second, and when I travel (which is quite often bc my family lives 3h away) I take the balm with me since it's so handy for travel, no spills lol. You could buy an oil if you want and rotate between that and the balm, just to see what you like üôÇ
